Environmental Initiatives

As owner and operator of the Esquimalt Graving Dock, Public Works and Government Services Canada is responsible for implementing programs to achieve its environmental objectives and targets. Examples of key environmental initiatives include:

Air Quality

Air quality is a significant environmental concern at the EGD. Control of paint overspray and dust is particularly important due to the proximity of the surrounding residential area and the marine environment.

An air quality monitoring station has been installed to provide instantaneous information on PM10 levels in the area (PM10: Particulate matter under 10 microns in size). The data provided allows the EGD to monitor the effectiveness of dust and paint control measures.


Top of Page

Wastewater and Storm Water

The EGD has implemented a number of initiatives designed to improve the quality of storm water discharges to the harbour and wastewater entering the sewer system. For example:

  • Oily wastewater generated at the EGD is collected for proper disposal, and may be processed by an on-site business that provides oily water separation and treatment services.
  • Grey and black water generated at the EGD is disposed of in accordance with local sewer authority requirements.
  • Upgrades to the storm water system allows for run-off to be treated through an oil and sediment separator, prior to its discharge into the marine environment. This system removes fine particles and oily substances from the storm water.
  • Oil spill sensor units installed at locations surrounding the EGD, provide operational staff with early detection of oil on the water. In the event of a spill that reaches the harbour, the units will initiate an alarm system to notify employees who are trained in spill response.

Top of Page

Solid Waste Reduction

The EGD's approach to waste management includes reducing, recycling, composting and purchasing supplies with recycled content. The EGD Recycling program includes office recyclables, waste batteries, ink cartridges and used oil products. A compost bin on site is also used for composting natural yard waste.


Top of Page

Hazardous Materials


Hazardous materials storage vault

To encourage diligence when managing hazardous materials at the Esquimalt Graving Dock, employees are trained in the proper handling, storage and disposal of materials such as oil, fuels, abrasive grit, paint, solvent, antifreeze and batteries. To continually improve worker safety and to reduce the risk of impacting the environment, the EGD has included guidelines for hazardous materials/waste management in the EGD's Environmental Best Management Practices Manual.

 


Top of Page

Energy & Water Reduction


Air-cooled compressor

The Esquimalt Graving Dock has implemented several initiatives to reduce energy use, decrease fresh water consumption and improve the efficiency of existing systems.

For example, an existing water-cooled air compressor was replaced with an air-cooled unit that dramatically reduces the amount of fresh water used. The heat generated from the compressor operation is also used for heating nearby workshops, providing additional energy savings.

Examples of other conservation measures include:

  • Installing of low flow spray nozzles for "water curtains" used for dust capture during sandblast operations
  • Utilizing compact fluorescent light bulbs for area lighting
  • Installing controls for powering off lighting and computer systems when not in use

Top of Page

Wildlife Protection

Bubble Curtain

When vessels enter and exit the Esquimalt Graving Dock, it is possible for marine life to enter the flooded dock and become stranded. As a safe, effective and inexpensive deterrent, an air bubble curtain was built into the Dock's entrance to discourage wildlife such as seals and fish from entering the dock space.


Bubble curtain in operation; Seal rescue prior to the bubble curtain

Unique Ecosystems

A portion of the Esquimalt Graving Dock property contains the remnants of a unique and endangered Garry Oak Ecosystem. A plant species inventory has been conducted on site to identify if at risk species exist in the area. The EGD has partnered with local Universities and community groups to protect and restore the natural state of the area.

Facility Improvements

A positive working environment is important for those working at the Esquimalt Graving Dock. Over time, the facility surroundings have been enhanced to reflect the cultural and historical values of the facility.
